I. Introduction to Python#

Overview & Characteristics#

  • [cite_start]General Purpose: Python is a general-purpose programming language used for various tasks, including search engines (Google), mission-critical projects (NASA), and financial transactions[cite: 129, 130].
  • [cite_start]Interpreted: Code is translated and executed by an interpreter one statement at a time, unlike compiled languages where the entire source code is compiled before execution[cite: 147, 148].
  • Object-Oriented: Data in Python are objects created from classes. [cite_start]A class defines properties and methods for manipulating objects[cite: 156].
  • [cite_start]History: Created by Guido van Rossum in the Netherlands in 1990 and is Open Source[cite: 160, 161].

Python 2 vs. Python 3#

  • [cite_start]Version Compatibility: Python 3 is a newer version and is not backward compatible with Python 2[cite: 167].
  • [cite_start]Course Standard: This course uses Python 3, though differences are minimal[cite: 174, 177].
  • Syntax Difference Example:
    • [cite_start]Python 2: print "text"[cite: 178].
    • [cite_start]Python 3: print("text")[cite: 178].

II. Programming Modes#

1. Interactive Mode#

  • [cite_start]Execution: Uses the Command Prompt or Shell to type python[cite: 8].
  • Limitations:
    • [cite_start]Not suitable for large programs[cite: 25].
    • [cite_start]Does not save statements; code cannot be reused in the future without retyping[cite: 26, 27].
    • [cite_start]Editing code is tedious as you must revisit previous commands[cite: 28, 29].

2. Script Mode#

  • [cite_start]Execution: Code is written in a file (e.g., using Notepad), saved with a .py extension, and executed via the command line[cite: 34, 40, 46].
  • [cite_start]Benefits: Allows for saving, editing, and running larger blocks of code [cite: 36-40].

III. Program Structure & Anatomy#

Basic Anatomy#

  • [cite_start]Statements: Represents an action or a sequence of actions (e.g., print("Welcome"))[cite: 288, 342].
  • Indentation: Indentation matters in Python. [cite_start]Statements must be entered from the first column or consistently indented (typically 4 spaces)[cite: 290, 350, 382].
    • [cite_start]Note: Incorrect indentation will cause an error[cite: 352].
  • Comments:
    • [cite_start]Used to document code, describe sequences, or temporarily disable lines [cite: 484-486].
    • Single Line: Starts with #. [cite_start]Anything after # is ignored by Python[cite: 305, 482].
    • [cite_start]Paragraph/Block: Enclosed in triple quotes """ or '''[cite: 360].

Planning with Pseudocode#

  • [cite_start]Definition: A method of planning that enables the programmer to plan without worrying about syntax[cite: 81].
  • [cite_start]Sequence: Based on the assumption that the computer executes the program from the beginning to the end (SEQUENCE)[cite: 57, 59].
  • [cite_start]Process: Think about the goal, run through the steps, and write them in simple English before typing the program[cite: 65, 66].

IV. Variables & Identifiers#

Variables#

  • [cite_start]Definition: A named place in memory where a programmer can store data and retrieve it later[cite: 521].
  • Assignment: Uses the = operator. [cite_start]The expression on the right is evaluated and assigned to the variable on the left[cite: 573, 574].
    • [cite_start]Example: radius = 20[cite: 419].
    • [cite_start]Simultaneous assignment is possible: x, y = y, x[cite: 615].
  • Named Constants: Python has no special syntax for constants. [cite_start]By convention, use all uppercase letters to denote a constant (e.g., PI = 3.14)[cite: 623, 624].

Identifier Rules#

  • [cite_start]Allowed Characters: Letters, digits, underscores (_), and asterisks (*)[cite: 491].
  • Starting Character: Must start with a letter or an underscore. [cite_start]Cannot start with a digit[cite: 492].
  • [cite_start]Case Sensitivity: Python is case sensitive (e.g., spam, Spam, and SPAM are different)[cite: 502, 506].
  • [cite_start]Reserved Words: Identifiers cannot be reserved words (keywords like if, while, class, import, return, etc.)[cite: 493, 513].

V. Data Types & Math#

Numerical Data Types#

  • [cite_start]Integer (int): Whole numbers (e.g., 3, -14, 0)[cite: 630, 639].
  • [cite_start]Float (float): Numbers with decimal parts (e.g., 3.0, 98.6, -2.5)[cite: 631, 640].
  • [cite_start]Scientific Notation: Floating-point literals can use e or E for exponents[cite: 678, 681].
    • [cite_start]Example: 1.23456e+2 is equivalent to 123.456[cite: 679].

Bash Functions and Files#

Functions in Bash#

  • Similar to shell script
    • Stores command for execution later in memory
    • Function executed in same shell as it was called in
  • Functions must be defined before they can be referenced
  • Typically placed at beginning of script
  • function_name(){
  statements
}
  • # Simple bash function
#!/bin/bash

# Function to print a message
say_hello(){
  echo "Hello, world!"
}
# Calling the function
say_hello
  • # Example with an argument
#!/bin/bash

# Defined function
greet_user(){
  echo "Hello, $1! Welcome to the world of bash scripting!"
}

# Call the function with an argument
greet_user "Jane"

Variables in Functions#

  • Variables defined within functions are global
  • Values are known throughout the entire shell program
  • Keyword ’local’ inside a function definition makes the referenced variable local to that function

Global and Local Variable examples#

  • global_var="Global"
show_variable(){
  local local_var="Local"
    echo "Inside the function"
    echo "Global variable: $global_var"
    echo "Local variable: $local_var"
}
show_variables

echo "Outside the function:"
echo "Global variable: $global_var"
# The local variable is not acessible outside the function
echo "Local variable: $local_var (not accessible)"

Working with File system in Bash#

  • Creating a new directory
    • mkdir DIRNAME
  • Creating a new file
    • Use text editor to create a new text file
    • Using the touch command

Naming for files and Directory#

  • Use Alphabetic letters
  • Numbers
  • Dot, underscore, hyphen
  • Avoid starting names with hyphens
    • Options usually start with hyphens
  • Avoid using spaces in file names
  • Avoid special letters, symbols ,etc.

Copying, moving or deleting#

  • # copying
cp [Source] [Destination]
# move
mv [Source] [Destination]
# Delete
rm FILENAME
rm -r [Directory]

Scanning files#

  • cat - concatenate, i.e. show file contents
  • more - show file contents one page at a time
  • less - better version of more with additional options
  • head - show first few lines of file
  • tail - show last few lines of a file
  • wc - show word, line and character count
  • sort - sorts file contents
  • uniq - removes duplicates
    • sort and uniq can be combined to extract unique values or do grouping
  • cut - picks out columns from tabular data
  • grep - search file contents (next module)
    • sed and awk are more advanced

The Linux filesystem#

  • Everything is a file, if not a file it is a process
  • There is basically no difference between a file and a directory

Types of files#

  • Most files are just regular files
  • There are the following exceptions:
    • Directories
    • Special files
    • Links
    • Domain sockets
      • Provide inter process networking protected by file system access control
    • Named pipes

File System#

  • Hierarchical - tree structure
  • Consistent
  • Simple - Flexible file operations
  • Directories are a special type of file that are lists of other programs
  • Ordered tree-like structure on the hard disk
  • Two types of paths - full/absolute paths and relative paths
    • Absolute path - complete path to a certain file or directory
      • All absolute file names start with a slash because the slash indicates the root directory
      • Slash also used for separating the directories on the path
    • Relative path- starts from the working directory
      • Need . and .. to indicate the working directory and the parent directory
  • Your shell uses your current directory as the point of reference

Basic Linux Directories#

File Permissions#

  • Users can belong to several groups
  • A file can only belong to one user and one group at a time
  • The root user has extra permissions
    • Only the root user can change the ownership of a file

Users and Groups#

  • User info in /etc/passwd
  • Password info in /etc/shadow
  • Group info in /etc/group
  • /etc/passwd and /etc/group divide data fields using “.”

Programs#

  • Programs can be run by a user, when the system starts, or by another process
  • Before starting the program, the kernel checks:
    • Is the file accessible to the user or group of the process that wants to run it?
    • Does the file containing the program permit execution by that user or group (or anybody)?
    • In most cases, a program inherits the privileges of the user/process who started it

Permissions#

  • Files owned by users and groups
  • Files have permissions for user, group and other (world)
  • Read, Write and Execute (R,W,X)
  • User who owns a file is always allowed to change its permissions

File Permissions#

  • Two ways to set permissions using the chmod command:
    • Symbolic mode:
    • Absolute mode:
      • Use octal (base 8 values)
      • R (read) = 4
      • W (write) = 2
      • X (execute) = 1
        • (none) = 0

Inherited permissions#

  • Two critical points
    • Permissions of a directory affect whether someone can see its contents or add or remove files in it
    • Permissions on a file determine what a user can do to the data in the file
    • Ex:
      • If you don’t have write permission for a directory, the you can’t delete a file in the directory
      • If you have write access to the file you can update the data in the file

Pattern Matching#

Pattern Matching essentials#

  • Pattern matching serves two roles in the shell
    • Selecting filenames within a directory
    • Determining whether a string conforms to a desired format
    • A pattern is a string with a special format designed to match filenames, or to check, classify or validate data strings

Pattern Matching with Wildcards#

  • Also referred to as glob patters used to match patters
    • Glob patterns are referred to in the Bash man page as “Pattern Matching”
  • In addition to the simple wildcard characters that are fairly well known, bash also has extended globing which adds features
  • Extended features are enabled via the extglob option

Example usage#

  - ![image.png](../assets/image_1763240105681_0.png)

Pattern Matching with Grep#

  • The grep command is a useful tool for filtering text based on patterns
  • Allows you to search for lines that match a specific pattern and display those lines
  • Grep commands provides various options and flags that allow you to customize the search and filtering process
  • Supports regex and can be used in combination with other commands to perform complex text filtering
  •   # Filtering lines containing the word apple in the file fruits.txt
  # This command will display all the lines that match the pattern
  grep "apple" fruit.txt
  •   grep <options> <search pattern> <files>

Pattern Matching with sed#

  • The sed command is another useful tool for string manipulation in bash scripting
  • Allows you to perform various operations on strings, such as substitution, deletion, and insertion
    • Provides a bunch of options and flags that allows you to customize the string manipulation process
    • Can be combined with other commands to perform string manipulation operations
  •   # Replacing "apple" with "orange" in a string
  string="I like apple pie."
  new_strings=$(echo $string | sed 's/apple/orange/') # s/apple/orange is used to specifiy the pattern to match and the replacement string
  echo "New String: $new_string"
  # This would output "I like orange pie."

Vulnerability Scanning#

Linux Logging Basics#

  • Provide a bunch of diagnostic information about the computer
  • Everything from kernel events to user actions is logged by Linux-allowing you to see almost any action performed on your servers

Linux System Logs#

  • Logs are stored in /var/log
  • Directory contains logs from the OS,services, and various applications running on the system
  • /var/log/syslog and /var/log/messages store all global activity data, including startup messages
  • /var/log/auth.log and /var/log/secure store all security-related events
    • Logins, root user actions, output from plugable authentication modules (PAM)
  • /var/log/kern.log stores kernel events, errors, and warning logs
    • Helpful for troubleshooting custom kernels
  • var/log/cron stores information aobut scheduled tasks (cron jobs)
    • Use this data to verify your cron jobs are running successfully

Syslog#

  • Standard for creating and transmitting logs
    • Can refer to the syslog service Syslog is a network-based logging protocol that monitors your systems and applications. This protocol provides a standard way for services and applications to report their logs. That way, they can be processed and redirected as needed.
      • Receives and processes syslog messages and listens for events
      • Can write messages to a local file or send to a remote server
  • A transport protocol specifying how to transmit logs over a network (RFC 5424)
    • It is also a transport protocol specifying how to transmit logs over a network
    • Also a data format to define how messages are structured
      • Default uses port 514 for plain text messages and port 6514 for encrypted messages
    • A syslog message is any log formatted in syslog message format and consists of a standardized header and message containing the logs contents
  • The syslog format and Fields
    • Timestamp
    • Name of the application that generated the event
    • Location in the system where the message originated
    • Priority
    • Can change the format in syslog config file but using the standard format makes it easier to parse analyze and route syslog events
    • Jun 4 22:14:15 server1 sshd[41458] : Failed password for root from 10.0.2.2 port 22 ssh2
<34>1 2019-06-05T22:14:15.003Z server1 sshd - - pam_unix(sshd:auth): authentication
failure; logname= uid=0 euid=0 tty=ssh ruser= rhost=10.0.2.2

Standardized message format#

  - Support the structuring of this message, **syslog facilities are available to denote which part of the system the log comes from**
    - Achieved by attaching a number to the message
  - **Priority** can be attached to a message using a number between 0 and 7

Security Auditing and System Hardening#

  • What is system hardening is the process of securing a system by reducing its attack surface
    • Involves disabling unnecessary services, configuring security settings, and applying updates
  • Why is it important?
    • Protects systems from unauthorized access or exploitation
    • Ensures compliance with security standards like CIS benchmarks

Key Components of System Hardening#

  • SSH Security
    • Disable root login and use key-based authentication
  • Firewall configuration
    • Use tools like ufw or iptables to control incoming and outgoing traffic
  • Service Management
    • Disable unnecessary services to reduce vulnerabilities
  • Regular Updates
    • Keeps the system updated with security patches

Bash for System Hardening#

  • Automates tasks like
    • Disabling services that might not be necessary
    • Updating packages
  • Ensures repeatability and consistency
  • Scripts can be scheduled via cron or other services

Using systemctl#

  - For example, using systemctl:
    - ```bash
      #!/bin/bash
      for service in bluetooth cups avahi-daemon; do
      systemctl stop $service
      systemctl disable $service
      done
      ```
    - Used to manage system services and the system state
    - Basic syntax:
      - ```bash
        systemctl [command] [unit]
        command [action] [#Start](Start.md), stop,etc.
        unit [systemd unit] [#Like](Like.md) a service, ex: nginx.service
        ```
      - ![Common systemctl commands](../assets/image_1763430376613_0.png)

Configuring Firewalls with Bash#

  • Best practices: 
    • ufw default deny incoming
uf default allow outgoing
    • Allow only the necessary ports
    • Turn ufw logging on
    • The ufw command
      • Simplified interface for managing iptables firewall rules
      • Basic syntax
      • ufw [command] [options]

User Account Security#

  • Best practices:
    • Enforce strong passwords using tools like passwd
      • Enforce strong passwords (passwd)
      • Lock unused accounts (usermod -L)
      • Use chage to enforce password aging
  • The passwd command
    • Manage user passwords on Linux systems
    • Basic syntax
    • # With no username, will change your own password
# With a username (as the root user): changes another user's password
passwd [options] [username]

Filesystem Protections#

  • Key steps
    • Remove world-writeable permissions from sensitive files
    • Configure /tmp with noexec to prevent the execution of files
      • noexec does not allow execution of any binaries on filesystem
      • Prevents accidental or malicious code execution from external drives
      • Prevents script execution from uploads
  • Best Practices
    • Writing a script that allows automatic updates
    • Ensures the latest security patches are applied automatically

Security Auditing and Advanced Scripting#

Introduction to security auditing?#

  • Process of evaluating a system’s security posture by identifying vulnerabilities
    • Examples:
      • user permissions
      • file permissions
      • network configurations
  • Why is it important
    • Helps to identify misconfigurations

Areas for Security Auditing#

  • User accounts
    • Check for empty passwords or unused accounts
  • File permissions
    • Identify world-writeable or SUID files
  • Network configuration
    • Verify open ports and firewall rules

Auditing User Accounts with Bash#

  - **Check for:**
    - Misconfigurations
    - Risks
    - Bad practices
  - Use cases
  - Scripts to check for empty passwords
    - Parse /etc/shadow to find accounts without passwords

Auditing File Permissions#

  - **Check for**
    - Weak
    - Risky
    - Misconfigured permissions
  - Use cases
  - **Find** world-writable files
    - **Find** command to locate files with insecure permissions

Auditing Network Configurations#

  - **Check for**
    - Open ports
    - Misconfigurations
    - Insecure services
  - Use case
  - Scripts to list open ports- use **netstat**
    - ```bash
      sudo netstat -tulnp [#Lists](Lists.md) all ports and thier associated proccesses
      ```

Creating Audit Reports in Bash#

  - Bash scripts used for automating system auditing tasks
  - Gather various pieces of information- such as:
    - System Information (OS, uptime, kernel version)
    - User Information (user accounts, active sessions)
    - File system usage (disk space, file permissions)
    - Service status (running services, open ports)
    - Security logs (failed logins, sudo usage)
  - ```bash
    #!/bin/bash
    echo "Security Audit Report" > audit_report.txt
    date >> audit_report.txt
    echo “Audit Data:" >> audit_report.txt
    ....
    echo "Audit report saved to audit_report.txt"
    ```

Linux Threat Hunting#

  • Proactive approach to identifying cyber threats
  • Be aware of the threat lanndscape
  • Detect and Respond to Cyber Threats

Why use Linux for Threat Hunting?#

  • Open-source
  • Transparent
  • Granular control

Process of Threat Hunting#

Threat Hunting Steps#

  • Trigger
    • Collect information about the environment and hypothesis
    • Choose a trigger for further investigation
    • Can be a system, network area, or hypothesis trigger by a vulnerability or patch or information about an exploit, security set anomalies or requests from other areas in the organization
  • Investigation
    • Hunting efforts are focused on proactive searching for anomalies
      • Can prove or disprove the hypothesis
      • Assumption \rarr “We are compromised or vulnerable to this new exploit”
      • Hunters use a wide range of tech to assist them in reviewing logs and investigating anomalies
  • Resolution
    • During the resolution phase, information is communicated to other teams and tools that can respond, prioritize, analyze, or store information for future use
      • Who? (if it involves credentials)
      • What? (the events that happened in order)
      • When? (exact timestamps for anomalies and incursions)
      • Where? (The scope of the affected systems, with lists of all devices and entities that will require remediation) and if possible from the evidence presented
      • Why? (Lack of adherence to security plan/guidelines, disgruntlement, careless, outside attack, etc.)
    • MITRE ATT&CK framework
      • Globally accessible knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real world operations

I. Decision Structures#

Introduction to Decisions#

  • [cite_start]Control Structures: While programs normally follow a sequential flow, control structures allow the program to alter this flow to suit specific situations [cite: 830-832].
  • [cite_start]Decision Structure: Also known as a “selection structure,” this allows a program to execute different sequences of instructions for different cases[cite: 839, 884].

The if Statement#

  • Syntax: 
    if condition:
    statement
    statement
  • Logic:
    • [cite_start]The condition is evaluated first[cite: 865].
    • [cite_start]If True: The indented statements are executed[cite: 867].
    • [cite_start]If False: The statements are skipped[cite: 868].

[Image of if statement flowchart]

I. Functions#

Introduction to Functions#

  • Definition: A group of statements within a program that performs a specific task.
  • [cite_start]Divide and Conquer: A strategy of breaking a large, complex program into smaller, modularized tasks (functions) [cite: 1012-1016].
  • Benefits:
    • Simpler code.
    • Code Reuse: Write once, call multiple times.
    • Better testing and debugging (test individually).
    • [cite_start]Faster development and facilitation of teamwork [cite: 1073-1079].

Types of Functions#

  1. [cite_start]Void Functions: Execute statements and terminate (do not return a value) [cite: 1087-1089].
  2. [cite_start]Value-Returning Functions: Execute statements and return a value to the calling statement (e.g., int(), input()) [cite: 1090-1092].

Defining and Calling#

  • [cite_start]Naming Rules: Cannot use keywords, cannot contain spaces, must start with a letter or underscore, and are case-sensitive [cite: 1100-1103].
  • Syntax: 
    def function_name():
    statement
    statement
  • [cite_start]Indentation: The block of statements belonging to the function must be indented consistently [cite: 1143-1144].
  • [cite_start]Main Function: Defines the mainline logic of the program and calls other functions as needed [cite: 1135-1137].

Designing with Functions#

  • [cite_start]Flowcharts: Function calls are depicted as rectangles with vertical bars at each side[cite: 1153].
  • [cite_start]Hierarchy Charts: (Structure Charts) Depict relationships between functions using boxes and connecting lines to show what calls what [cite: 1173-1174].
  • [cite_start]The pass Keyword: Can be used to create empty functions as placeholders during design[cite: 1195].

Variables and Scope#

  • Local Variables: Created inside a function and belong only to that function. [cite_start]They cannot be accessed by code outside the function [cite: 1205-1207].
  • Scope: The part of the program where a variable may be accessed.
  • Global Variables: Created outside all functions. Accessible anywhere but make debugging difficult and programs hard to understand. [cite_start]Avoid usage [cite: 1340, 1348-1353].
  • Global Constants: Global names referencing unchangeable values. [cite_start]These are permissible[cite: 1358].

Arguments and Parameters#

  • Argument: Data sent into a function call.
  • [cite_start]Parameter: The variable inside the function that receives the argument[cite: 1243].
  • [cite_start]Pass by Value: Changes made to a parameter inside the function do not affect the argument outside the function [cite: 1287-1288].
  • [cite_start]Keyword Arguments: Specifies which parameter a value belongs to (e.g., func(parameter=value)), allowing arguments to be passed out of order [cite: 1331-1332].

Return Values#

  • Syntax: return expression.
  • Multiple Values: Python can return multiple values separated by commas.
    • [cite_start]Example: return expression1, expression2 [cite: 1527-1528].
  • [cite_start]None: A special value meaning “no value,” often used to indicate errors [cite: 1533-1534].

II. Modules and Standard Library#

Standard Library#

  • Definition: Pre-written functions that come with Python (e.g., print, range).
  • Modules: Files that store library functions. [cite_start]To use them, you must use the import statement [cite: 1386-1389].

The random Module#

Requires import random. Useful functions include:

I. Sequences and Lists#

Sequences#

  • Definition: An object that contains multiple items of data stored one after another.
  • [cite_start]Types: Python provides different types of sequences, mainly lists (mutable) and tuples (immutable) [cite: 715-717].

Lists#

  • Definition: A mutable object that contains multiple data items (elements).
  • Format: list = [item1, item2, etc.].
  • Characteristics:
    • [cite_start]Can hold items of different data types (e.g., integers, strings, floats) [cite: 722-725].
    • print() can display the entire list.
    • list() function converts other objects to lists.

List Operations#

  • Repetition Operator (*): Creates multiple copies of a list joined together. [cite_start]Format: list * n [cite: 749-752].
  • Iteration: You can iterate over a list using a for loop: 
    for item in list:
    # process item
  • Indexing:
    • Position of an element (starting at 0).
    • [cite_start]Negative indexes count from the end (-1 is the last element) [cite: 760-763].
    • len(list) returns the number of elements.
  • [cite_start]Mutability: Elements can be changed using their index: list[1] = new_value [cite: 779-781].
  • [cite_start]Concatenation (+): Joins two lists together [cite: 787-788].
  • [cite_start]Slicing: Extracts a span of items: list[start : end] [cite: 795-797].

List Methods & Built-in Functions#

Method/Function Description Citation
append(item) Adds item to the end of the list. [cite_start] [cite: 816, 838, 845]
index(item) Returns the index of the first occurrence of item. [cite_start] [cite: 817-818, 839, 846]
insert(index, item) Inserts item at a specific position. [cite_start] [cite: 825, 840, 848]
sort() Sorts list in ascending order. [cite_start] [cite: 827, 841, 853]
remove(item) Removes the first occurrence of item. [cite_start] [cite: 828, 842, 854]
reverse() Reverses the order of elements. [cite_start] [cite: 829, 843, 855]
del list[i] Removes element at specific index. [cite_start] [cite: 860-861]
min() / max() Returns lowest/highest value in the sequence. [cite_start] [cite: 862]

Copying Lists#

  • Reference vs. Value: list1 = list2 only makes list1 reference the same object as list2 (modifying one affects the other).
  • True Copy: Create a new list and copy elements:
    1. Create empty list and append loop.
    2. [cite_start]Concatenate existing list to a new empty list (new_list = [] + old_list) [cite: 870-873].

II. Advanced List Features#

List Comprehensions#

  • Definition: A concise expression to create a new list by iterating over an existing one.
  • [cite_start]Basic Syntax: [item for item in old_list][cite: 909, 928].
  • [cite_start]Calculations: [item**2 for item in list] creates a list of squares[cite: 943].
  • [cite_start]Filtering (if clause): [item for item in list if item < 10] includes only items meeting criteria[cite: 964, 971].

Two-Dimensional Lists#

  • Definition: A list containing other lists as elements (nested list), often representing rows and columns.
  • [cite_start]Processing: Typically requires nested loops to process data (two indexes needed) [cite: 977, 981-982].

III. Tuples#

  • Definition: An immutable sequence (cannot be changed once created).
  • Format: tuple_name = (item1, item2).
  • Operations: Supports indexing, slicing, len(), min(), max(), and in operator.
  • Limitations: Does not support append, remove, insert, reverse, or sort.
  • [cite_start]Advantages: Faster processing than lists and safer (data cannot be accidentally modified) [cite: 1010-1015, 1025-1030, 1037-1038].

IV. Plotting with matplotlib#

  • [cite_start]Installation: Not standard; install via pip install matplotlib[cite: 1056].
  • [cite_start]Import: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt[cite: 1075].
  • Line Graph: plt.plot(x_coords, y_coords) connects points.
  • Bar Chart: plt.bar(left_edges, heights, bar_width, color).
  • Pie Chart: plt.pie(values, labels=slice_labels).
  • [cite_start]Display: plt.show() renders the graph [cite: 1081, 1257, 1361-1362].

V. Dictionaries#

Introduction#

  • Definition: An object that stores a collection of data as key-value pairs (mappings).
  • Format: dictionary = {key1: val1, key2: val2}.
  • Keys: Must be immutable objects (e.g., strings, numbers, tuples).
  • Retrieval: dictionary[key]. [cite_start]Raises KeyError if key is not found [cite: 1409-1416, 1425-1426].

Operations#

  • Adding/Modifying: dictionary[key] = value. [cite_start]If key exists, value is updated; otherwise, new pair is added [cite: 1436-1437].
  • Deleting: del dictionary[key].
  • [cite_start]Length: len(dictionary) returns number of pairs[cite: 1443, 1450].
  • Methods:
    • clear(): Empties the dictionary.
    • get(key, default): Safely retrieves value without KeyError.
    • items(): Returns all keys and values as tuples.
    • keys(): Returns all keys.
    • values(): Returns all values.
    • [cite_start]pop(key): Returns value and removes pair [cite: 1468-1471, 1479, 1490-1491].

Dictionary Comprehensions#

  • Syntax: {item: item**2 for item in list}. [cite_start]Creates a dictionary from a sequence [cite: 1516-1517, 1539].

VI. Sets#

Introduction#

  • Definition: An unordered collection of unique elements (no duplicates allowed).
  • Creation: set_variable = set(argument). Argument must be iterable.
  • Mutability: Sets are mutable; elements can be added/removed.

Set Operations#

  • Adding: add(item) or update(sequence).
  • Removing: remove(item) (raises error if missing) or discard(item) (no error).
  • Set Math:
    • Union (|): Contains all elements from both sets.
    • Intersection (&): Contains only elements found in both sets.
    • Difference (-): Elements in the first set but not the second.
    • [cite_start]Symmetric Difference (^): Elements in either set, but not both [cite: 1613-1614, 1620-1623, 1641-1646, 1653-1658, 1675-1681].
  • [cite_start]Subsets/Supersets: issubset (<=) and issuperset (>=) [cite: 1687-1691].

VII. Serializing Objects#

  • Definition: Converting an object to a stream of bytes to store in a file (Pickling).
  • Process:
    1. import pickle
    2. Open file for binary writing ('wb').
    3. Pickle: pickle.dump(object, file).
    4. [cite_start]Unpickle: pickle.load(file) (requires opening file for binary reading 'rb') [cite: 1749-1750, 1759-1763, 1768-1773].

I. Classes and Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)#

Procedural vs. Object-Oriented#

  • Procedural Programming: Writing programs made of functions that perform specific tasks. [cite_start]Procedures operate on data items that are separate from the procedures [cite: 2680-2681].
  • Object-Oriented Programming (OOP): Focuses on creating objects. [cite_start]An object is an entity that contains both data (attributes) and procedures (methods) [cite: 2689-2690].

Core OOP Concepts#

  • [cite_start]Encapsulation: Combining data and code into a single object[cite: 2693].
  • Data Hiding: An object’s attributes are hidden from code outside the object. [cite_start]Access is restricted to the object’s methods to protect from accidental corruption [cite: 2706-2708].
  • [cite_start]Object Reusability: The same object can be used in different programs[cite: 2710].

Classes vs. Instances#

  • Class: Code that specifies the data attributes and methods for a type of object. [cite_start]It acts as a blueprint or cookie cutter [cite: 2733-2734].
  • [cite_start]Instance: A specific object created from a class (e.g., a specific house built from the blueprint)[cite: 2735].

Defining Classes#

  • Syntax: 
    class ClassName:
    def method(self):
        # statements
  • The self Parameter: Required in every method. [cite_start]It references the specific object instance the method is working on[cite: 2771].
  • The __init__ Method: Also known as the initializer. It is automatically executed when an instance is created to initialize attributes [cite: 2777-2778].
  • Creating Instances: 
    my_instance = ClassName()
    [cite_start][cite: 2803].

Attributes and Methods#

  • [cite_start]Hiding Attributes: To make an attribute private, place two underscores before the name (e.g., __current_minute)[cite: 2813].
  • Accessor Methods (Getters): Return a value from an attribute without changing it[cite: 2882].
  • [cite_start]Mutator Methods (Setters): Store or change the value of an attribute[cite: 2883].
  • The __str__ Method: Returns the object’s state as a string. Automatically called when the object is passed to print() [cite: 2834-2835].

Class Design (UML)#

  • UML Diagram: Unified Modeling Language. Depicted as a box with three sections:
    1. Class Name
    2. Data Attributes
    3. [cite_start]Methods [cite: 2896, 2898-2901].
  • Finding Classes: Look for nouns in the problem description. [cite_start]Refine the list by removing nouns that represent simple values or duplicates [cite: 2926-2929, 2954-2957].

II. Inheritance#

Concepts#

  • “Is a” Relationship: Exists when a specialized object has all characteristics of a general object plus specialized ones (e.g., A poodle is a dog; a car is a vehicle) [cite: 3000-3003].
  • Inheritance: Defines a new class that borrows behavior from another class.
    • Superclass: The general class being borrowed from.
    • [cite_start]Subclass: The new specialized class doing the borrowing [cite: 3015-3016].

Benefits#

  1. [cite_start]Avoids Duplication: Common methods (e.g., homeAddress) are defined once in the superclass[cite: 3041].
  2. [cite_start]Code Reuse: New classes are based on existing ones[cite: 3043].

Syntax Example#

class Parent:
  def func1(self):
      print("Hello Parent")

class Child(Parent): # Inherits from Parent
  def func2(self):
      print("Hello Child")

I. Introduction to Libraries#

What is a Library?#

  • Definition: A collection of pre-combined codes used iteratively to reduce coding time. [cite_start]It allows access to pre-written, frequently used code instead of writing from scratch [cite: 2271-2272].
  • Concept: Similar to physical libraries, they are a collection of reusable resources. [cite_start]This concept is the foundation of open-source libraries in Python [cite: 2273-2274].
  • [cite_start]Purpose: They extend the capabilities of the language by providing tools and modules for specific tasks [cite: 2282-2283].

Benefits of Using Libraries#

  • Reduced coding time and effort.
  • Improved code quality and reliability.
  • Increased readability and maintainability.
  • [cite_start]Access to a wide range of functionality and reduced development costs [cite: 2336-2340].

Structure of a Python Library#

A library is typically structured as a directory containing:

Bash fundamentals#

  • Bash is a shell- prints the prompt and interprets
  • Bash is the root of scripting
  • Shell scripts are common on Unix and Linux systems
  • Shells scripts evolved from a workflow
    • Sequence of commands placed in a file
    • Command line options enable different options to be passed to commands
    • Introduce variables, if tests, loops enables more complex programming flow
  • Can also be an intermediary between other languages

Bash Terminal and Commands#

Using the shell#

  • ~ is a shorthand for home directory in this case

Example commands#

  •   [username@scc1 ~]$ command --option argument
  • Command- does one thing
  • Options- change the way command does the thing
  • Argument-provides input/output that the command interacts with
  • Can use man or info to get info
  • History command to see shell history

Variables#

  •   USER=test
  echo $test
  export $test
  • Too see environment variables use the printenv command

Input Output in Bash#

  • I/O is important to interact with users, data processing, automation and scripting tasks, interaction with other programs, error handling
  • Bash input-received data from user
  • Bash output-refers to info or data that the program generates or writes

File Descriptors#

  • Standard input - stdin
    • Interactively read input from user from another command using standard input
  • Standard output - stdout
    • Allows you to display output using standard output
  • Standard error- stderr
    • Handles error messages

File Redirection#

  • Basic I/O manipulation
  •   echo "This is example code" > story
  cat story
  cat < story

Pipelines#

  • Redirect output of command into standard input
  •   ls -l | more

Bash Conditionals#

  • Allow scripts to make decisions
  • Execute different commands based on conditions
  • Control flow

Types of conditional statements#

  • if
  • if else
  • elif (else if)

If statement#

if [ condition ]; then
  commands
fi

If-else statement#

if [ condition ]; then
  commands
else
  commands2
fi

elif statement#

if [ condition1 ]; then
  commands1
elif [ condition2 ]; then
  commands2
else
  commands3
fi

Comparison operators#

  • • -eq (equal) • -ne (not equal) • -lt (less than) • -le (less than or equal) • -gt (greater than) • -ge (greater than or equal)
  • • = (equal) • != (not equal) • -z (empty string) • -n (non-empty string) 
    num=10
if [ $num -gt 5 ]; then
  echo "The number is greater than 5"
fi

Logical operators#

  • && (AND)
  • || (OR)
  • ! (NOT)

File Test operators#

  • • -f (is a file) • -d (is a directory) • -e (exists) • -r (is readable) • -w (is writable) • -x (is executable) 
    # Example of checking a file
if [ -f "file.txt" ]; then
  echo "The file exists"
else
  echo "The file does not exist"
fi

• Aesthetics \rarr Philosophical study of Art and Art making
  • Dramatic dramatization
  • Translation and Transformation
  • Shifting the terrain and dramatizing things
  • Choices made all the time
  • Live in a mediatized age \rarr We are all connected to language
  • What is a medium (as a person)
    • Types of paper and art
  • Choice
  • Nostalgia and history
  • Memory and Protection
  • Is the audience immersed?
  • Simulacra and Hyperreal \rarr Pretending to be real.
  • Almost like video games are the real world, but not truly
  • Genre/reasons
  • Experiences
  • Accountability and Ethics
  • Abstract
  • Pondering
  • Thinking about what is
  • Perception/ relationship between actions and ideas

item.title: Module 1 (Gilgamesh)
item.description:
• **

    General Notes

  • Stories date back as far as 2100

  • 1700 BCE

  • 600 standard version- Babylonian

  • Believed that the epic may have been a school text

  • Text was first deciphered in mid 1800’s

  • Key form script

    Tablet I

  • Toys with the people of the earth

    • The king is Brutal- his subjects complain to Ishtar

  • Temple in Rome

  • Ishtar complains to the higher up gods

  • Spy for Gilgamesh tames the beast through sex

item.title: Module 2
item.description:
• **
  • Unknown if Homer was one person or multiple
    • May have inserted himself into his works as a type of self-portrait
  • The Illiad
    • Exists within 900 year space- most likely originally transcribed from oral history
  • Transcribed approx 1 century after conception
  • 16,000 lines long and composed 10 years before war between the Greeks and the Trojans.
    • The Trojan war
    • This war took place approx 4 years before the piece was written
    • We start in the middle of the war
  • Talks of the flood-almost like in Gilgamesh
    • Couple spared in the flood and tasked with repopulating the earth through throwing stones (the bones of the earth)
  • Troy is the western coast of Turkey
    • Several layers have been excavated in this region discovering cities (9)
    • Some evidence of war in this region from excavations
    • The Hittite kingdom was located near the East of the Troy - can easily make cultural references/connection
  • The Trojan war is started by the Judgement of Paris in which he chooses Aphrodite for love over two other Goddesses, Athena and Hera/ Paris seduced Helen, wife of Spartan Lord Menelaus. Menelaus seeks the aid of his brother Agamemnon.
    • The content of the poem centers around Achilles, the greatest warrior of Agamemnon’s forces
  • Angered the god Apollo by kidnapping Chryseis- the daughter of the high priest Chryses
  • Forced to give up this woman, Agamemnon takes Achilles concubine Briseis in return, angering Achilles and provoking the warrior to “sit out” the war. He will return
  • Achilles is accidentally killed
    • Tension in this poem is that of the immortality of the gods and the mortality of the humans
  • Achilles must reconcile himself to his own mortality
  • Gods have to recognize just how much they’ve become- involved and immersed in human activity
    • Gilgamesh and the Iliad have many similarities
    • The Trojan horse
  • The Odyssey
    • Multiple narratorial perspectives, Odysseus tells his story in the first person in the middle.
    • Dactylic Hexameter is a line of poetry with six metrical feet (one strong stress and two weak stresses)
    • Major spaces: The main hall of Odyseeus kingdom
  • Coming of age, growing old
  • The collateral of war
  • Wit and intellect over sheer fore
  • Arbitrary acts of the gods and the powerlessness of humanity

The Odyssey#

Books 1-8#

  • We start with summary of the whole: “He came to see / many people’s cities, where he learned their customs, / while on the sea his spirit suffered many torments” (1.3-5)]
    • Almost like a muse
  • We begin with an assembly of the gods, with Zeus and Athena speaking (Athena loves Odysseus for his cunning and his battle prowess) Zeus: “How could I forget godlike Odysseus, / pre-eminent among all mortal men for his intelligence and offerings / to the mortal gods” (1.66-68)
  • Some linkage to the Illiad
  • The gods will send Hermes, the messenger god, to Calypso, who holds Odysseus on her island (he’s been there seven years) Athena goes to Ithaca, to Odysseus’ palace where his son, Telemachus must entertain suitors to his mother (vying for her hand in marriage with Odysseus gone so long and presumed dead). Note the **hospitality **of Telemachus to the disguised goddess; hospitality is a significant theme in this text, so obsessed with feasting! Notice the contrast between Telemachus and the suitors. Notice too how the bard Phemius performs a song of Achaeans returning from Troy (but Penelope stops him from singing that “painful song” (1.276).
    • Odysseus is a poor young man
    • Hospitality is a central theme of the text and the culture as a whole
  • The idea that when aiding a stranger, you actually might be aiding a god or gods in disguise- you may be rewarded for your actions- so be kind
  • Telemachus is angry with all the suitors- Athena advises Telemachus to sail off and seek the word of his father (King Nestor in Pylos and the to Menelaus in Sparta)
    • ““If you think it’s better and would prefer / that one man’s livelihood should be consumed / without paying anything, I’ll call on / the immortal gods to see if mighty Zeus / will bring about an act of retribution” (1.319-23)”
    • “Telemachus spoke, then threw the scepter on the ground / and burst out crying” (2.52-53).
    • Wily Penelope quote about the suitors- sounds similar to her husband Odysseus
  • “you [suitors] must wait, / although you are keen for me to marry, / till I complete this cloak—for if I don’t, / my weaving would be wasted and in vain” (2.74-77) [but, after four years, she is betrayed by one of her women]
  • Female characters are shown throughout the text weaving (including Athena)- a metaphor for how the narrative of the story is being shaped and spun over time
  • Betrayed by a female servant who thus ends her resistance to the suitors (cant stop them)
  • Athena roams Ithaca in disguise as Telemachus to recruit sailors for him in order to ensure that he is able to depart in a swift manner
    • In Book 3 (omitted from your books), Telemachus will sail to Peleponnese (southern Greece) and journey by land to the city of Pylos where he will be entertained by his father’s old comrade, King Nestor. The King offers his own account of the battles at Troy and his return home to Pylos. The King will send Telemachus on, further, to Sparta to see Menelaus. Nestor’s son, Pisistratus (same name as later Athenian ruler) will accompany Telemachus.
  • Telemachus compares the Hall of Menelaus to Zeus’s kingdom- and is corrected by Minnelaus:
    • “No man alive could rival Zeus, dear boys, / with his everlasting palace and possessions” (4.87-88).
  • Meleanus grieves for Odyseus and recognizes Telemachus by his resemblance to his father
    • Helen’s and Menelaus’ account of Odysseus sneaking into Troy as a beggar and, then, the Trojan Horse: “We heard you [Helen] call. / Two of us—Diomedes and myself—were eager to get up and charge outside / or else to answer back from where we sat, in side the horse. But Odysseus stopped us—/we wished to speak, but he held us in check” (4.86-90)
    • Helen admits that she might have been drugged in Troy
    • We are reminded of the characters own mortality
  • Athena appeals to the gods to aid Odysseus, who is still trapped on the island with Calypso and has been for 7 years. Athena describes the ambush that is being set for Telemachus. Hermes goes to Calypso to tell her that Odysseus must leave the island. Further establishes the theme of mortality vs immortality

    • Odysseus sits regularly by the sea “his eyes always full of tears / because he was squandering his sweet life, mourning / for his return” (5.100-103).

item.title: Module 3
item.description:
EH 242 Module 3 Notes#

Introduction#

  • Publius Ovidius Virgil
    • Contemporary of Virgil
  • Wrote erotic love poetry
    • The Amores
    • The Ars Amoritia
    • The Remedia Ammoris
  • Banished in 8CE by Emperor augustus- “carmen et arrow”
  • Lived out his last years in on the Black Sea
  • Far from rome
  • Books completed about the time of Ovid’s banishment
  • 15 books engaging mythological history from creation of the earth till Julius Caesar.
  • Changes to epic and myth
  • Cruelty and selfish nature of the gods
  • Language and change

Book 1#

  • Speaks of forms in different bodies
  • Bring the lengthened narrative from beginning of world

Summary#

  • Ovid invokes the gods and asks them to help with his work
  • Talks about the creation of the world
    • Similar to the creation story in the Bible
    • 4 ages follow
  • The Age of gold
    • Trust, moral goodness, fruitfulness
  • The age of Silver
    • People have to work for a living
  • The age of bronze
    • First wars but some morality persists
  • Age of Iron
    • Nothing is sacred
    • Even turning against members of your own family
    • Gods appear and witness the issues with the humans

      • Jupiter visits house of Lycaon- who treats him with great disrespect

item.title: Module 4
item.description:
Sundjata#

General plot structure#

  • The plot is divided into the following sections:
    • Paternal ancestry of Sunjata
    • Buffalo-woman tale
    • Birth and childhood of Sunjata
    • Exile of Sunjata
    • Return and war with Sumanguru
  • Nare Maghann Konate receives a hunter on his court
    • Hunter predicts that if Konate married an ugly woman, she would someday produce him a son that would someday become a great king
    • The king is already married to a woman
    • When two hunters from another kingdom present him a woman named Sogolon - the king remembers the prophecy and marries her
  • She produces a son that is unable to walk throughout his childhood
  • Sassouma jealous of the child and mother and would make fun of his inability to walk
  • Despite his physical weakness king still grants him Griot (West African storyteller)
    • Provide consolation to him
  • Death of the king occurs and his first son (Dankaram Tuman) assumes the throne despite Konate’s wishes that the prophecy be respected
    • Sundiata and his mother who had given birth to two daughters and adopted a second son from Konate’s third wife Namandje
  • Suffers scorn of new king and mother
    • Insult against Sogolon, Sundiata breaks an iron rod that he got from the blacksmith as he tries to pull himself upwards and to stand
    • Sundiata is able to walk after his father dies and his mother orders him to do
  • Sundiata is able to walk after his father dies
  • Hatred of Sassouma Berete and Dankaran Toumani Keita drove Sundiata and his family into exile
    • Neighboring kingdoms are unwilling to harbor them
  • While living in the Mema kingdom Sundiata grows as “strong as a lion”
    • Fought with a great general of the Mema people
    • Became a great warrior
    • Sogolon encouraged him to “fulfill his destiny” and return to Mali to become the king
  • Soumaoro Kante a historical leader of the Sosso people who rose to prominence after demise of Ghana empire
    • Portrayed in the epic as a cruel sorcerer king
    • Attacked the Mandinka kingdom
  • Causes Dankaran Toumani to take flight in fear
    • Soumaoro has conquered nine kingdoms in the former Ghana empire
  • Oppressed Mandinka people then sent for the exiled Sundiata
  • Forges a coalition of neighboring small kingdoms
    • Sundiata wages a war against the Sosso
  • Crowned as the Mansa (“King of Kings”)
  • First ruler of the Mali empire
  • Set about organizing the empire
    • Presenting Gbara of nobles and notables at his coronation with oral constitution
    • Model for governance that persists into the future

Africa’s as the Cradle of Civilization#

  • Africas great drift valley
    • Where the story of humanity likely begins
  • Evidence that the anatomically modern humans emerged in the continent of Africa.
    • Belief that humans began walking on the earth much earlier than possible
    • Likely to find more evidence as time goes on
    • We are all likely descended from African American ancestors - common ancestors in Africa
    • Around 80000-50000 years ago humans began to spread out through the rest of the world
    • Caves in Africa show the first signs of Human artistic expression on the walls
    • Face paintings sometimes used to communicate/identify
  • 10000 years human began to breed animals and eventually start going towards domestication
  • Eventually move to the area near the source of a Nile and become the ancestors of Humans

Webcast 1#

African Empires#

  • Umayyad caliphate controls much of upper Africa and the Middle East
  • African Empries
    • Ghana (Wagadou) (8th-11th century)
    • Al Moravids (11th-12th century)
    • Al Mohads (1147-ealy 13th century)
    • Mali (early-13th century)

Medieval West Africa- Mali Empire#

  • This is the context for the story
  • Rise of the Sossos (Kaniaga) and Sousaomo Kante Sosso (sorcerer king in the story)
  • Revolt against Sossos including Mali- Plot of story
  • Battle of Krinia (1235)- Sundiata defeats the Sossos and unifies Mali Kings
  • First sub-saharan people to accept Islam
  • Traders begin to have prayers in thier towns
  • Set up in the Sharia system
  • King employs Muslim interpreters
  • City contains 12 mosques- 1 mosque for congressional prayers
    • Designed a mosque featuring an inner court with the exact dimensions of Kabba in Mecca
    • Became a center of education
    • Mosque sees visitors almost constantly
    • Temple creates a large library of texts-many of which survive to today
    • Also accumulated navigational maps from explorers.
    • The Mali empire was one of the largest in the world at the time
  • King was Maza Abu Boukahri
  • Studied at St Corie univesity
    • Read a text saying that the Atlantic ocean was not the edge of the world and then he studied ocean currents
  • Perform an expedition with 200 ships amply stocked for the expedition
    • Captain told him of success and would build upwards of 2000
  • In 1311 hands over the government and title of Mansour to his brother
    • Fufill dream of sailing across the Atlantic
      • Beleived that they took off but likely did not make
      • Christopher columbus may not have been the first person to cross the ocean
        • Unknown if they made it back
  • Aby Boukhari interested in extending borders of the empire to east toward Cairo
  • Caputred neighboring cities in order to expand the empire
  • Richest man in history (at the time)- Mansa Musa

Griots#

  • 20th century girot Mamodou Kouyate provides this version of the Suniata
  • “The future springs from the past”
  • Griots’ importance to political as “memory”
  • Haji pilgramages
    • Ambulate the Kabba
  • Many versions of the story
  • “Living memory” books

Important Themes#

- Third epic
- Hunting and gathering
  • Hunters songs
  • Appalachia songs
  • Blues songs

Webcast 2 (4-21)#

“l am a hunter chasing game and come from Sangaran…” (4) “The hunters of Sandaran are the best soothsayers” (4) “The left hand is the hand of evil” (5) “Mali is about to emerge from the night” (5)

item.title: Part 1
item.description:
Chapter 1#

  • Sound beings with the vibration of an object
    • Sound transmitted by a medium
  • Music is part of the world of sound

Pitch: Highness or Lowness of Sound#

  • Pitch → Highness or lowness of a sound
  • Sound that has a definite pitch is called a tone
    • Has a specific frequency
    • Vibrations of a tone are regular and reach the ear at regular intervals
    • Tones will sound different with different pitches
  • Interval of an octave - interval between first and last tones of the scale
    • Octave has seven different pitched before arriving at the high note which duplicates the first one
    • 7 tones on the keyboard
    • Added 12 tones are duplicated in higher and lower octaves
  • Distance is known as the pitch range
  • Most music is based on definite pitches

Dynamics#

  • Dynamics → Degrees of loudness or softness are known as
    • Loudness or softness affects the type of the sound
  • Italian terms indicate dynamics
  • Ways to indicate dynamical changes
  • Not super precise
    • Tone has a dynamic level - in relation to other tones around the instrument or vocal

Tone Color#

  • Tone color or Timbre descriptions
    • Bright
    • Dark
    • Brilliant
    • Mellow
    • Rich
  • Even though instruments might sound the same, the sound that the instrument creates will likely vary

Chapter 2#

Voices#

  • Singing demands a greater control of pitch and volume
  • Range of singers voice depends on training and physical makeup
  • Professionals usually have a vocal range of about 2 octaves

Musical Instruments#

  • Any mechanism other than a voice that produce musical sounds

item.title: Part 2
item.description:
Chapter 11- Music in the Middle Ages#

  • Most important musicians were priests and worked for the church
    • Liturgical singing
    • Boys received music education in schools associated with churches and cathedrals
  • Most medieval was vocal- musicians also performed on a wide variety of instruments
    • “pronouncing the words of the Holy spirit”
  • Instruments incorporated into church music after 1800
  • We don’t know much about how medieval music sounded- most of the instruments have been destroyed

Gregorian Chant#

  • Official music of the Roman Catholic church for over 1000 years
  • Designed to enhance specific parts of religious services
  • Conveys calm, otherworldly quality
    • Flexible rhythm, no meter, little sense of beat
    • Almost an improvisational character, due to the lack of beat and flexible
  • Named after Pope Gregory 1= 590-604
  • Originally passed down through oral tradition, later notated
  • Composers completely unknown

The Church Modes#

  • Gregorian chant results partly from unfamiliar scales
    • “Church modes”
  • Same as major and minor scales, but half steps are different

Secular music in the Middle Ages#

  • Secular music → Music outside of the church
    • 13th century
    • Dance in wooded places, parties, etc.

Troubadour and Trouvere Song#

  • Active in courts of the nobility and in towns during the 12th and 13th centuries
    • Troubadours- Live in southern France and write poems in the Provencal language
    • Trouveres- Flourish in northern France and write in Old French
  • Mostly about courtly/idealized love for the idea noble lady
  • Different backgrounds- some nobles, some have modest backgrounds
  • Notated as single melodic lines
    • Monophonic texture

Minstrels#

  • Entertained in castles, public places, etc.
    • Perform music, told stories
  • Lowest social level with no civil rights
  • Not many found steady work
  • Important source of info because there were no newspapers

The Development of Polyphony: Organum#

  • Type of polyphony
  • Original music in this time had a single melodic line
  • Monks in monasteries begin to add a second melodic line to Gregorian chant
    • Originally improvised
  • Duplication of original melody at diff pitch
    • Developed a melodic curve of its own
  • 1100- not restricted to a note against not style
  • Lines could differ rhythmically as melodically

School of Notre Dame: Measured Rhythm#

  • 1150- Paris becomes a center of polyphonic music
    • Measured rhythm - definite time values and clearly defined meter
    • Notation describes precise rhythm and pitches
    • By modern standards, medieval polyphony is hollow and thin
  • Lack of triads
    • 2 intervals of a third

14th Century Music: The “New Art” in France#

  • ars nova
  • Secular music becomes more important than sacred music
  • Composer could specify any rhythmic pattern
    • Beats can be subdivision
    • Syncopation becomes important
  • Leonin and Perotin - measured rhythm, definite time values and rhythms
    • Notation indicated precise rhythms as well as pitches

Guillaume de Machaut#

  • Born in French province of Champagne
  • Spent much of his life in the service of many royal families
  • Traveled to many courts and presented his music to various royals
  • Music consists mostly of love songs
  • Mass Ordinary -texts that remain the same from day to day throughout a church year

Chapter 2: Music in the Renaissance#

  • 1450-1600
  • Renaissance idea of the “universal man”
  • Church remains an important patron of music but musical activity gradually shifts to the courts
    • Church choirs grow in size
    • People in positions of power compete for the finest composers and musicians

Characteristics of Renaissance Music#

Words and Music#

  • Vocal music more important than instrumental music
    • Humanistic interest in language vocal music
  • Close relationship between words and music
    • “Word painting” → Musical depiction of specific words
    • Emotion expressed in a moderate, balanced way, no extreme contrasts of dynamics

Texture#

  • Renaissance music is chiefly polyphonic
    • Imitation among the voices is common
    • Homophonic texture with successions of chords is also used
  • Sounds much fuller than medieval music
  • Did not need instrumental accompaniment

Rhythm and Melody#

  • Gentle flow than a defined beat
  • Each singer must maintain an individual rhythm

Sacred Music in the Renaissance#

  • Motet and the mass are the two forms of Renaissance music
    • Motet
  • Polyphonic choral work set to a sacred Latin text
    • Mass
  • Polyphonic choral composition made up of five sections

Josquin Desprez and the Renaissance market#

  • Compositions have masses, motes, and secular vocal pieces
  • Ave Maria
    • Opening uses polyphonic imitation
    • Short melodic phrase is presented by a soprano voice and then imitated in turn by the alto, tenor, and bass
    • Motet- 2,3 or 4 voices can be heard at the same time
  • Duets between high voices imitated by the lower parts
  • Almost homophonic at times

Palestrina and the Renaissance Mass#

  • Palestrina music includes 104 and 450 sacred works
  • 1500s and Catholic church was challenged and questioned by the Protestants
  • Jesuit order founded to strengthen the church
  • Convening of the council of Tent considers questions of dogma and organization
    • Church music should be composed to inspire religious contemplation
  • Palestrina’s emphasis works reflect an emphasis on more spiritual music

Pope Marcellus Mass#

  • Kyrie - rich polyphonic texture
    • Curved melody
    • Upward leaps balanced by downward steps

Secular Music in the Renaissance#

Vocal Music#

  • Secular music becomes increasingly popular
  • Development of music printing helps to increase the spread of music
    • Music becomes an important leisure activity
  • Renaissance secular music was written for groups of solo voices and for solo voice with the accompaniment of one or more instruments
  • Madrigal - a piece for several solo voices set to a short poem, usually about love
    • Originated during a creative explosion in Italy around 1520
    • Uses word painting and unusual harmonies more often

Thomas Weelkes#

  • Written to Honor Queen Elizabeth

Renaissance Lute Song#

  • Lute is a plucked string instrument
  • Lute song cultivated from the late 1590s to the 1620s
    • Mostly homophonic in texture

John Dowland#

  • “Flow my Tears”
    • ABC section repeated - AA BB CC
    • Song about hopelessness but has uplifting moments

Instrumental Music#

  • Becomes more important during the Renaissance
    • Able to be free from vocal music in the 16th century
    • Instrumental music intended for dancing
  • Renaissance musicians distinguished between loud and soft instruments

Michael Praetorius#

  • Passamezzo and Galliard pair contrasting court dances and triple meter

item.title: Part 4
item.description:
Romanticism in Music#

  • About 1820-1900
  • Franz Schubert, Robert Schumann, Clara Wieck Schumann, Hendel, Dvorak, etc.
  • Continued to use the musical forms of the classical era
    • Emotional intensity was already present in Classical work
  • Romantic music usually have a greater range of tone color, dynamics and pitch
    • Harmonic vocabulary is broader
  • More emphasis on colorful, unstable chords
  • Linked more closely to other arts- literature

Characteristics of Romantic Music#

Individuality of Style#

  • Expression of the individual and the individuality of self
  • Tchaikovsky, Chopin, Schumann were some of the pioneers of this style

Expressive Aims and Subjects#

  • Flamboyance and intimacy, unpredictability, melancholy, rapture and longing
    • Glorification of Romantic love
    • Fantastic and Diabolical
  • Dream of a Witches’ sabbath
  • All aspects of Nature attracted Romantic musicians
  • Subjects drawn from the Middle Ages and Shakespeare

Nationalism and Exoticism#

  • Composers create music that express a National Identity
  • Exoticism → Composers drawing on colorful materials from foreign lands

Program Music#

  • Program Music → Instrumental music associated with a story, poem or idea
    • Can represent the emotions, characters, and events of a particular story. can evoke the sounds and motion of nature
    • Romeo and Juliet - Tchaikovsky
  • Music matches the mood of the scene

Expressive Tone Color#

  • Rich and sensuous sound
    • Timbre is extremely important
    • Romantic orchestra is larger and more varied in tone color than the classical orchestra
  • 100 ish people
  • 20-60 in classical
    • Brass, Woodwind, Percussion take on a more active role
  • Brass
    • Trombones, Trumpets, etc
  • Woodwind
    • Bass Clarinet
    • English horn
    • Piccolo
  • Composers want to blend and combine tone colors
  • Piano vastly improved during the 1820s and 1830s
    • Piano tone became more “singing”
    • Range extended
    • Pianist could produce more sound due to a larger instrument
    • Damper pedal allowed for blend of tones from all registers of the piano

Colorful Harmony#

  • Explored new chords/existing chords
  • Emphasized greater emotional intensity, rich, colorful and complex harmonies
  • Chromatic harmony → Uses chords containing tones not found in the prevailing major or minor scale
    • Chromatic scale
    • Add color and motion to romantic music

Expanded Range of Dynamics, Pitch, Tempo#

  • Sharp contrasts between dynamics
    • ffff, pppp, etc.
    • More expressiveness- use crescendos, etc
    • Often accompanied by changes in pace

Form: Miniature and Monumental#

  • Thematic transformation - change the melody as it returns later in a piece by changing dynamics, etc.
  • Different movements of a romantic work can be linked together through transitional passages

Romantic Composers and Their Public#

  • Composers role in society changed greatly during the time of Beethoven
    • Part of the musicians job had been the composition of works for a specific occasion and audience
    • Bach wrote cantatas for weekly church services
    • One of the first musicians to work freelance
  • This image of Beethoven inspired romantic writers
  • Romantic composers were interested in pleasing those around them and being judged fairly by posterity
    • Free artists by necessity rather than choice
  • Many aristocrats could not afford to have court musicians
  • Romantic composers wrote primarily for a middle class audience
    • Citizens expanded dramatically and people want to hear music
  • First half of the nineteenth century witnessed the founding of music conservatories throughout Europe
    • Captured by virtuosity
  • Private music making also increased during the romantic era
    • Piano becomes a fixture in middle class homes
  • Romantic composers came from the social class that was their main audience
  • It was difficult for children to make a living through music
    • Most composers were forced to work at many areas at work

Sonata Form#

  • Sonata form → Refers to the form of a single movement

    • Exposition → Themes are presented

item.title: Part 5
item.description:
Chapter 5#

The Art song (lied)#

  • Art sing is a composition for solo voice and piano
    • Accompaniment is a integral part of the composers concept
  • Original meant to be sung at home, not at concert halls
  • Poetry and music are fused in the art song - flourished with increasing amount of romantic poetry
  • Song composers would interpret or translate a poem into musical form

Song Forms#

  • Strophic form makes a song easy to remember and is used in almost all folk songs
    • Repeats the same music in each stanza
  • Through composed forms writes new music for each stanza
    • Used to reflect poems changing moods

The Song Cycle#

  • Romantic songs are usually grouped in a set or, song cycle
    • Sometimes unified by a story line that runs through poems or by musical ideas that link the songs

Franz Schubert#

  • 1797-1828
  • Earliest master of the Romantic art song
  • Never held an official position- made his income entirely through composition
  • Schubert was born in Vienna, son of a schoolmaster
  • Composed a large number of works in his late teenage years
  • Wrote Gretchen am Spindale and The Erlking
  • Composed close to 200 works per year
  • Most of his works were designed to be performed for the middle class
  • Did not mingle with the aristocracy
  • Died in 1828 at the age of 31

Schubert’s Music#

  • Schubert composed over 600 works
  • The melodies of his songs have a larger variety of moods and types.
    • Some folklike tunes to complex lines that suggest impassioned speech
  • Schubert’s harmonies and dissonances provide some poetic moments in music
  • Spirit of song permeates Schubert’s music too
    • Symphonies and chamber works have longer lyrical melodies
  • Most of his famous Trout Quintet in A minor
  • Most of the symphonies and chamber works have long, lyrical melodies which are sometimes comparable in power and intensity to those his idol
  • Erlking is a great example of musical romanticism
    • Piano part builds the excitement of the work
    • Also the piano parts unifies the episodes of the song and suggests the horse’s gallop
  • Schubert varies the music makes one signer sound like several characters in a miniature drama

Robert Schumann#

  • 1810-1856
  • His works are autobiographical and usually have descriptive titles, texts, or programs
  • Born in Germany and studied law at Leipzig university
    • Devoted most of his time to music
  • Had an issue with his hand that sometimes hampered his ability to play music

Schumann’s Music#

  • Composed many art songs in 1840

Clara Wieck Schumann#

  • Leading concert pianists of the nineteenth century
  • 1819-1896
  • Premiered many works by her husband, Robert Schumann and by Johannes Brahms
  • Was the daughter of Marianne Wieck
  • Father trained her to be a child prodigy who would both earn money and demonstrate the superiority of his teaching methods
  • Continued to concertize and compose though on a reduced scale while caring for seven children
  • After Robert Schumann’s death, Clara expanded her performance activities
  • Considered herself primarily a performance artist
  • In recent times, the compositions have become more and more performed

Fredric Chopin#

  • 1810-1849
  • Wrote almost exclusively for the piano
  • Son of a Polish mother and French father and was brought up in Warsaw
  • At 21 moved to Paris which was the center of romanticism and the artistic capital of Europe
    • Gained access to aristocratic salons
    • Preferred salons to concert halls - conceived short pieces such as the nocturnes, preludes and waltzes
  • Died of tuberculosis at 39 years old

Chopin’s Music#

  • Personal and original styles
  • Miniatures- Most of his pieces evoked a variety of moods and are elegant, peaceful and melodic
    • His melodic gift creates the illusion that the piano is signing
  • Composed Nocturne in E flat major, Op 9, No 2 when he was around 20
    • Slow, lyrical composition for piano
    • Opens with a Legato melody containing graceful upward leaps, which become more wide as the line unfolds
    • Melody occurs three times throughout the piece
    • Includes a subordinate melody that is played with slight fluctuations in the tempo
    • Widely spaced notes in the accompaniment
  • Rev Etude in C minor
    • May have been inspired by the Russian takeover of Warsaw in 1831
    • Speed and endurance is developed in the Pianists left hand, which plays rapid passages throughout
    • A A’ Form
    • High dissonant chords and downward rushing passages lead to the main melody
    • At the end of the A’

Franz Liszt#

  • 1811-1886
  • During the 1840s performed superhuman feats on the piano
    • Overwhelms the European public
    • Impressing musicians and the concertgoing public
  • Born in Hungary
    • Studied in Vienna at age 11, met Schubert and Beethoven
    • Moved to Paris in teens and twenties
    • Met Pagani, a violinists, and resolved to become greater at the piano, came back to stage life a couple of years later as a great pianist
  • Composed the Transcendental Etudes and made Piano transcriptions of Paganins violin pieces
  • At 36 became a court conductor in Wien mar to establish himself as a serious composer
    • Provided free piano education to Gifted individuals
  • Became president of the New Academy of Music

Liszt’s Music#

  • Created the Symphonic poem- a one movement orchestral composition based to some extent on literary or pectoral ideas

Felix Mendelson#

  • Romantic whose music was rooted in classical tradition
  • Born in Hamburg Germany
    • Young prodigy
  • Conducted Bach’s St Matthews Passion in its first performance since Bachs death
    • Rekindled interest in Bachs music
    • Earned him an international reputation
  • Often visited and played for Queen Victoria
  • Personal life more conventional than most romantic composers

Fanny Mendelssohn Hensel#

  • Older sister of Felix Melssohn
